awd_titl_txt: Conference: Toward a Holistic Developmental Science: Catalyzing Transdisciplinary Multi-Sector Collaborations to Understand and Support Human Development
awd_abstract_narration:
Research to understand the complexities of human development occurs in a diverse array of fields. Whereas specialization within a field is essential to address research questions at a deep level, this has resulted in fragmented silos of knowledge. However, innovations are catalyzed when research intentionally integrates multiple disciplines and is conceptualized with policymakers, practitioners, and the community (e.g., transdisciplinary, multisector research).  Despite its importance, transdisciplinary, multisector research is difficult to achieve. This project provides funding to support the attendance of early career and underrepresented scholars at a conference specifically focused on catalyzing innovative, transdisciplinary, multisector research and a 6-month follow up meeting at a preconference before the Society for Research in Child Development (SRCD) Biennial Meeting. This conference upends the traditional conference model by providing opportunities to pursue training, mentorship, and structured space to foster new collaborations across attendees’ disciplinary training and is integrative among researchers, community agencies, and practitioners. 

This conference emphasizes the process of building and sustaining multidisciplinary and multisector collaborations. To achieve this, keynote speakers and plenary sessions will focus on how to develop transdisciplinary, multisector teams and projects. The main impetus of the conference emerges from the Working Roundtables, whereby attendees are pre-matched based on submissions into transdisciplinary and multisector teams and provided dedicated time and mentorship to develop new innovative transdisciplinary, multisector research ideas. Supporting attendance at this conference will encourage and enable a new generation of transdisciplinary, multisector research focused on understanding and supporting human development in its full and rich complexity.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Behavioral and Cognitive Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: PRESIDENT AND FELLOWS OF HARVARD COLLEGE

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: Hilton St. Louis at the Ballpark

por.por_cntn:
Research on human development has deepened and broadened, and thus straddles several intellectual disciplines, theoretical orientations, and multiple methodologies. However, training for research in human development often occurs in the context of single disciplines. Further, understanding human development requires that research is multisector.  This means working in collaboration with community agencies, school districts, governmental agencies and others who work directly with children and adolescents.  However, most research is driven by scientists often detached from the populations they study. As such, to understand human development, the field needs transdisciplinary and multisector research. The importance of and difficulty in achieving interdisciplinarity, multidisciplinary, and transdisciplinary work cannot be understated. To this end, the major goal of this conference grant was to host a structured and intentional conference to catalyze the transdisciplinary, multisector research that is essential for understanding and supporting human development. In organizing the conference, we focused on the following goals:

1)   To provide training on establishing transdisciplinary, multisector research teams through plenary sessions showcasing exemplars of transdisciplinary research, and structured time and resources to break down the barriers to conducting transdisciplinary research and catalyze new research projects.

2)   To create a conference context that included practitioners and agencies that serve children, youth and families as contributing partners and collaborators.

3)   To host a conference that is “upside down,” focusing on catalyzing new ideas rather than presenting findings from completed work.  The conference organizers invited researchers, practitioners, and funders to submit their best ideas for developing new multisector, transdisciplinary research projects, along with open-mindedness in order to generate novel, innovative, and significant research projects.

4)   To increase the likelihood of engagement and collaboration beyond the conference days, another goal was to provide support for 10 scholars from underrepresented backgrounds to attend the conference supported by this grant and attend a preconference session for mentorship and training at the Biennial Meeting of the Society for Research in Child Development (SRCD) six months later in March, 2023

We hosted the conference in collaboration with the Society for Research in Child Development on September 29-30, 2022 in St. Louis, MO.  Attendance was capped at 150 people to create an intimate environment that would facilitate discussion and collaboration. The conference was attended by 151 people. The program included 134 submissions, including 17 Plenary sessions, 42 posters, 56 working roundtables, and 9 policy-maker, practitioner, and funder presentations. Working roundtables were an innovative conference offering that enabled the organizers to match attendees into working groups that were diverse in their disciplinary background and research methods but aligned in their research topical interest/expertise.  These groups were the heart of the conference. It is from the working roundtables that new innovative, transdisciplinary, multisector research would be incubated.  The conference was structured to include keynote addresses and invited plenary panels, along with extensive time for the working roundtables to collaborate and plan new projects.

To meet the fourth goal, thirty-two early career scholars applied for the 10 fellowships that were funded by this NSF award.  Of these, 23 identified as being from an underrepresented group. These included ethnic minorities, first generation college students, attending a non-R01 college or university, or attending a Historically Black College or University. All 10 awards were made, which funded these scholars to attend the NSF supported, Holistic Developmental Science conference, and the large Biennial Meeting of the SRCD, which took place in March, 2023 in Salt Lake City. The SRCD Biennial Meeting brings in nearly 6000 developmental scientists from around the world to present and discuss the latest research in developmental science. It was an ideal context for the preconference mentoring session and then launching the fellows to present work and network in the large Biennial Meeting.

To further our goal of catalyzing new innovative research projects that are transdisciplinary and cross sector, we raised additional funds through the Society for Research in Child Development and the American Psychological Association to support three Seed Grants that conference attendees could apply for.  These small grants enabled three working roundtable teams to take the next step in launching their projects. 

Together, the funding from this NSF conference grant demonstrated intellectual merit in catalyzing new and innovative research in developmental science.  There are several broader impacts from the conference. This conference encouraged and enabled the integration of community voices and perspectives into developmental science. Additionally, this conference provided professional development and training opportunities, which emphasized the process of building and sustaining multidisciplinary and multisector collaborations. Further, this innovative conference broadened participation of early career, international, and scientists from underrepresented backgrounds by supporting their travel and attendance at this conference and the 2023 SRCD Biennial Meeting.

 


Last Modified: 11/29/2023
Modified by: Nancy E Hill

To this end, the major goal of this conference grant was to host a structured and intentional conference to catalyze the transdisciplinary, multisector research that is essential for understanding and supporting human development. In organizing the conference, we focused on the following goals:


1) To provide training on establishing transdisciplinary, multisector research teams through plenary sessions showcasing exemplars of transdisciplinary research, and structured time and resources to break down the barriers to conducting transdisciplinary research and catalyze new research projects.


2) To create a conference context that included practitioners and agencies that serve children, youth and families as contributing partners and collaborators.

The conference organizers invited researchers, practitioners, and funders to submit their best ideas for developing new multisector, transdisciplinary research projects, along with open-mindedness in order to generate novel, innovative, and significant research projects.

We hosted the conference in collaboration with the Society for Research in Child Development on September 29-30, 2022 in St. Louis, MO. To further our goal of catalyzing new innovative research projects that are transdisciplinary and cross sector, we raised additional funds through the Society for Research in Child Development and the American Psychological Association to support three Seed Grants that conference attendees could apply for. Additionally, this conference provided professional development and training opportunities, which emphasized theprocessof building and sustaining multidisciplinary and multisector collaborations. Further, this innovative conference broadened participation of early career, international, and scientists from underrepresented backgrounds by supporting their travel and attendance at this conference and the 2023 SRCD Biennial Meeting.
